FILM2900.001: Introduction to Film Studies (FC: HU)

Instructor: Amanda Ann Klein

Times Offered: Tuesday & Thursday, 9:30-10:45 am

Film screenings: Tuesday, 6:30 pm

The goal of this course, as its title suggests, is to “introduce” you to the broad field of film studies, including formal analysis, genre studies, film history and theory. By the end of the semester you will have the basic critical tools necessary for understanding and analyzing the language of motion pictures. Ideally, this course will enable you to not only gain a richer understanding of the films you watch but also the television shows, You Tube videos, commercials, and other media you encounter on a daily basis.

Screenings: Upstream Color (2013, Shane Carruth), Casablanca (1942, Michael Curtiz), Breathless (1960, Jean-Luc Godard), Touch of Evil (1958, Orson Welles), The Virgin Suicides (1999, Sofia Coppola), Written on the Wind (1959, Douglas Sirk), The Bicycle Thieves (1948, Vittorio De Sica), Twilight (2008, Catherine Hardwicke), Jackie Brown (1997, Quentin Tarantino)

****FILM2900 is a required course for the Film Studies minor core****

FILM2900.002: Introduction to Film Studies (FC: HU)

Instructor: Randall Martoccia

Times Offered: Monday, Wednesday, Friday, 1:00-1:50pm

Film screenings: Monday, 6:30-9:30pm

The goal of this course, as its title suggests, is to “introduce” you to the broad field of film studies, including formal analysis, genre studies, film history and theory. Years ago, a Film 2900 student said that the course taught him how to watch movies in the way a film director does. Even if you don’t have that reaction, by the end of the semester you will have the basic critical tools necessary for understanding and analyzing the language of motion pictures. Ideally, this course will enable you to not only gain a richer understanding of the films you watch but also the television shows, You Tube videos, commercials, and other media you encounter on a daily basis.

Films: Modern Times (1936), Dir. Charlie Chaplin), Citizen Kane (1941), Dir. Orson Welles, Bicycle Thieves (1948), Dir. Vittorio De Sica, Psycho (1960), Dir. Alfred Hitchcock, Fight Club (1999), Dir. David Fincher, Goodfellas (1990), Dir. Martin Scorsese, Zero Dark Thirty (2012), Dir. Kathryn Bigelow, Do the Right Thing (1989), Dir. Spike Lee

****FILM2900 is a required course for the Film Studies minor core****

FILM2900.003: Introduction to Film Studies (HU)

Instructor: Dr. Anna Froula

Class Time: Monday and Wednesday, 2:00-3:15pm

Film screenings (not mandatory): Monday, 6:30pm

(When possible, I have selected many films that stream on Netflix and Hulu)

The goal of this course, as its title suggests, is to “introduce” you to the broad field of film studies, including formal analysis, genre studies, film history and theory. By the end of the semester you will have the basic critical tools necessary for understanding and analyzing the language of motion pictures. Ideally, this course will enable you to not only gain a richer understanding of the films you watch but also the television shows, You Tube videos, commercials, and other media you encounter on a daily basis

Films: His Girl Friday (Hawks, 1940), Queen of Versailles (Greenfield, 2012), The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (Schnabel, 2007), The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance (Ford, 1960), Silver Linings Playbook (Russell, 2012), The Killer (Woo, 1989), The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari (Wiene, 1920) and The 400 Blows (Trauffaut, 1959)

****FILM2900 is a required course for the Film Studies minor core****

ART 2480.001: Visual Storytelling

Instructor: Ken Wyatt

Times Offered: Tuesday, 6:00-8:50 pm

Film Screenings: In class

This course examines the commonalities between documentary, narrative, corporate, music video, and experimental forms, production practices and their potential interaction. While grading will be based on a number of factors the overriding purpose of this class is to demonstrate your ability to develop an idea that conveys a clear story to the audience using the tools and time available.

Screenings: City of God(2003, Fernando Meirelles) Rope (1948, Alfred Hitchcock), Gridlock’d (1997, Vondie Curtis-Hall), Glengarry Glen Ross (1992, James Foley), Full Metal Jacket (1987, Stanley Kubrick), and Meshes of the Afternoon (1943, Maya Deren)

****ART2480 counts as an elective course for the Film Studies minor****

FORL 2600: Foreign Literature in Translation/The Holocaust (FC:HU)

Instructor: Susanne Lenné Jones

Times offered: Tuesday & Thursday, 3:30-4:45pm

Film screenings: various times

In this course we will examine the history of the Holocaust and its changing representation in film, literature and theoretical texts, reflecting specifically Jewish, German, and European ways of thinking about the past seventy-odd years of their history. Discussions will focus on the origins of anti-Semitism and other National Socialist justifications for genocide as well as on theories of Sigmund Freud, Primo Levi, and Saul Friedlander treating the psychology of mourning, repression, trauma, and memory, and apply them to the postwar reactions of Holocaust survivors in poetry, literature, and film.

Screenings: Triumph of the Will (Leni Riefenstahl, 1935), Jüd Süss (Veit Harlan, 1940), Europa, Europa (Agnieszka Holland, 1990), Sophie’s Choice (Alan J. Pakula, 1982), Valkyrie (Bryan Singer, 2008), The Nasty Girl (Michael Verhoeven, 1991), Life is Beautiful (Roberto Benigni, 1997), Downfall (Oliver Hirschbiegel, 2004), Under The Domim Tree (Eli Cohen, 1995), and The Reader (Stephen Daldry, 2008).

****FORL2600 counts towards the Multicultural/Transnational/International Film Cognate for Fall 2016 semester****

FORL 2760: Latin American Culture through Cinema (FC:HUM)

Instructor: Jennifer M. Valko

Times offered: Monday & Wednesday, 2:00-3:15 pm

Screening: On your own (+ occasional screenings)

Explore a variety of Latin American cultural obsessions like soccer, music, dance, and politics. Learn the basics to analyze films. Explore the major Latin American Film industries. Consider the tension between creating domestic (Latin American) cinema while competing with Hollywood in the past and in the present. Discuss issues related to history, social class, immigration, gender, and ethnicity in Latin America. Emphasis placed on contemporary films. No knowledge of Spanish necessary!

Earn Foundations HUM Credits! All films in Spanish with English subtitles.

Tentative Screenings: The Maid (2008, Silva), Sleep Dealer (2008, Rivera), The Milk of Sorrow (2009, Llosa), Chico and Rita (2010, Trueba, Mariscal & Errando), The Liberator (2013, Arvelo), Juan of the Dead (2011, Brugués), The Unbeatables (2013, Campanella), Bad Hair (2013, Rondón), Cantinflas (2014, del Amo), & Wild Tales (2014, Szifrón).

****FORL2760 counts towards the Multicultural/Transnational/International Film Cognate for Fall 2016 semester****

SOCI 3025-001: Sociology of Mass Media

Instructor: Dr. Sitawa R. Kimuna

Class times: Tuesday & Thursday, 11:00– 12:15 pm

Film Screenings: In class

The class will examine the importance of mass media in shaping and creating cultural perceptions. The goal of the course is to provide students with the knowledge and skills to critically analyze mass media, especially, how it is organized and presented for public consumption. One of our first tasks will be to explore the way media texts are produced. We will then examine media content paying particular attention to the construction of meaning. We will go beyond overly-simplified discussions of stereotypes to address cultural products as open texts subject to a variety of interpretations, some of which may subvert intended readings. We will also investigate patterns and processes of media consumption (including questions of media effects, the ways in which consumption choices may serve to create or erode boundaries between groups of people, and how knowledge of elite cultural forms act as currency that may advantage or disadvantage consumers). Some of the films that will be screened in class for critical analyses include:

Films: Happy Feet (2006, George Miller); Maid in Manhattan (2002, Wayne Wang); She Hate Me (2004, Spike Lee); The Devil Wears Prada (2006, David Frankel); The Informant (2009, Steven Soderbergh); Dirty Pretty Things (2002, Stephen Frears); It’s Kind of a Funny Story (2010, Anna Boden and Ryan Fleck); American Violet (2008, Tim Disney), and Doubt (2009, John Patrick Shanley); Boys Don’t Cry (1999, Kimberly Peirce); Brokeback Mountain (2005, Ang Lee); Crash (2004, Paul Haggis); Guess Who’s Coming to Dinner (1967, Stanley Kramer).

****SOCI3025 counts towards the Multicultural/Transnational/International Film Cognate for Fall 2016 semester****

ENGL 3810: Advanced Composition (WI) (DE)

Instructor: Joyce I Middleton

Times offered: DE

Screening: on your own

This DE section of advanced composition focuses on writing about film as a rhetorical text and as a visual rhetoric. Students will learn how “to read” films beyond their simple entertainment value and to analyze how films work rhetorically for their audiences; then they will write about them. Students will practice writing in a variety of genres that will help them to develop skills for analyzing film, writing, peer editing, analyzing images, and writing about visual rhetoric in film. This class satisfies the ECU writing requirement. Discussion board assignments and 2 papers. No exam.

Screenings: Contagion (2011, Soderbergh), Traffic (2000, Soderbergh), Inception (2010, Nolan), Temple Grandin (2010, Jackson), Jurassic World (2015, Trevorrow), Sicario (2015, Villaneuve), The King’s Speech (2010, Hooper), The Martian (2015, Scott), The Equalizer (2014, Fuqua), Boyhood (2014, Linklater), The Man from U.N.C.L.E. (2015, Ritchie), The Theory of Everything (2014, Marsh), Mad Max: Fury Road (2015, Miller), Guardians of the Galaxy (2014, Gunn), A Better Life (2011, Weitz), Quartet (2012 Hoffman) or other film titles on DVD; permission of the Instructor required.

****ENGL3810 counts as an elective course for the Film Studies minor core****

FILM3900: American and International Film History, Part I

Instructor: Dr. Anna Froula

Class Time: Monday and Wednesday, 3:30-4:45pm

Film screenings (not mandatory): Monday, 6:30pm

(When possible, I have selected many films that stream on Netflix and Hulu)

Before Edward glittered and Eric seduced, Nosferatu lurked. Before George Clooney charmed, Cary Grant enchanted. Before Charlie Sheen shocked, Fatty Arbuckle scandalized. How much have our stars, our stories, and our storytelling devices changed from the invention of cinema? Find out as we study the major films, genres, regulatory bodies and economic structures that defined cinema, both American and international, from its inception in the mid-1890s through the onset of World War II.

Films: Scarface (Hawks, 1932), J’Accuse! (Gance, 1938), It (Badger, 1927), The Passion of Joan of Arc (Dreyer, 1928), The Playhouse (Keaton, 1925), The Big Parade (Vidor, 1925), I Am a Fugitive from a Chain Gang (LeRoy, 1932), Man with a Movie Camera (Vertov, 1929), White Zombie (Halperin, 1932)

****FILM 3900 counts towards the Film History Cognate for the Film Studies Minor***

FILM 4920: Women, Identity and Difference in American Cinema

Instructor: Amanda Ann Klein

Times offered: Tuesday & Thursday, 11:00-12:15 pm

Film screening: streaming titles will be used

This seminar explores the different ways that American cinema has attempted to represent women. Beginning with the documentary Miss Representation, this course explores how American cinema represents women from different races, economic classes, sexual orientations, ethnicities and body types. The course will explore different facets of a particular American identity from the perspective of mainstream films (Pretty Woman) as well as independent (Tangerine) and experimental entries (Spring Breakers). In addition to looking at isolated identities and what it means to be an African American, white, working class, or a disabled woman in America, this course will also focus on intersectionality, or the ways that multiple systems of oppression are felt on individual bodies and how they intersect. This FILM course is also cross-listed with WOST.

Screenings: Miss Representation (2011, Jennifer Siebel Newsom and Kimberlee Acquaro), Spring Breakers (2012, Harmony Korine), Boys Don’t Cry (1999, Kimberly Pierce),Little Darlings (1980, Ronald F. Maxwell), Precious (2009, Lee Daniels), The Joy Luck Club (1993, Wayne Wang), Children of a Lesser God (1986, Ronda Haines), Real Women Have Curves (2002, Patricia Cardoso), Tangerine (2015, Sean S. Baker)
